trans-unit.id: Light also carries energy, and the amount of energy depends on the wavelength: the shorter the wavelength, the more energetic the light beam is. Take short wavelength UV light for example: a little is good for the tan, but too much can cause sunburns! Conversely, longer wavelengths are associated with weaker energies. But the cold gas lying in between stars, or some cold dust particles for example, emit low energy radiations at long wavelengths that fall into the Radio domain.

Porque se propagan fácilmente a través de la atmósfera e incluso por debajo del agua. El dominio «radio» es un amplio espectro de longitudes de onda, que se extienden desde magnitudes kilométricas hasta milimétricas. La forma en que se propagan depende en gran medida de su longitud de onda y nosotros nos aprovechamos de estas formas distintas de propagación para crear nuestros complejos y diversos sistemas de comunicación.

trans-unit.id: Kilometre wavelengths propagate through surface waves and follow the curvature of the Earth. With enough emission power, they can reach up to 1000 km. They also propagate under water, that’s why they are often used by submarines. Be careful though, it’s not Sonar! Sonar stands for SOund Navigation And Ranging. It’s a technique that uses sound propagation underwater, not light! Amateur radio operators use decametre wavelengths. These wavelengths are very interesting because they are reflected by the Earth’s ionosphere. This means that an amateur radio signal sent to the sky bounces onto the ionosphere back to Earth, and propagates very far. Sometimes it can even reach the antipodes! Why sometimes? Well the reflection processes depends on the state of the ionosphere. Wavelengths below about a metre propagate directly in straight lines from the emitter, almost like visible light. It’s the domain of FM broadcasting, TV emission, Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, etc. These wavelengths are less affected by the ionosphere, that’s why we need satellites to relay them and send them back to Earth.

trans-unit.id: So radio waves are light, not sound. How come I can listen to my favourite songs with my radio? Well, suppose you want to share a song with your friend, 100m away from you. You could shout it very loudly but it would require a huge amount of energy to be heard, which would most likely result in a sore throat and some angry neighbours… Instead you could use your flashlight, translate it into Morse code and send it to your friend. By doing that, you have solved the problem of energy and distance, but you have lost a lot of information in the process. To keep all the information, you have to code the light you are sending in a specific way, so that your friend can receive and decode it easily. This is called signal processing. Frequency Modulation (FM yes, like in FM radio!) is a kind of signal processing that is very easy and cheap to implement. You just modulate the light signal you are sending (the carrier wave) by varying its instantaneous frequency according to that of your message (your song for example). The signal is sent «modulated», and your radio «demodulates» it back to its original form and transmits it to its speakers, thus converting light back into sound!

Con esta solución hemos superado el problema de «energía» y «distancia», pero hemos perdido información en el proceso.Para mantener toda la información, tendremos que codificar la luz que estamos enviando de una manera específica: así nuestra amiga la podrá recibirla y decodificarla con facilidad. A esto le llamamos «procesamiento de señal»La Frecuencia Modulada (FM, sí... ¡como en la radio FM!) es un tipo de procesamiento de señal fácil y barato de implementar. Solo requiere modular la señal de luz que se desea enviar (la onda portadora) haciendo variaciones en su frecuencia instantánea de acuerdo con aquello que contiene el mensaje (nuestra canción, por ejemplo). La señal se envía «modulada» y la radio de nuestra amiga la «descodifica» hacia su forma original para transmitirla a los altavoces. Esto es... ¡convirtiendo la luz nuevamente en sonido!

trans-unit.id: The ionosphere is a layer of electrons and other electrically charged particles in the upper atmosphere. It starts at around 80 km from the ground. At this altitude, the atmosphere is too thin to shield the particles from the Solar radiation. Atoms and molecules are hit directly with very energetic light like UV and X-Ray, and this causes them to break and lose some electrons. Their neutral balance is disturbed and they become electrically charged. The resulting mixture of electrons and charged particles is called plasma, and it is responsible for the reflection power of the ionosphere at decametre wavelengths. During the day, Sunbeams hit the ionosphere and produce a lot of charged particles; the ionosphere becomes unstable and cannot reflect the radio signals very efficiently. But at night, the ionosphere is less perturbed and almost acts as a smooth mirror. This is why amateur radio operators prefer to send their long-distance call during the night!

A esta altitud, la atmósfera es demasiado delgada para blindar a las partículas de la radiación solar. Los átomos y las moléculas son golpeados directamente con luces de alta energía como la ultravioleta (UV) o los rayos-X. Esto causa su ruptura y la pérdida de algunos electrones. Su balance neutral se ve perturbado y se convierten en partículas cargadas de electricidad. La mezcla resultante de electrones y partículas cargadas se conoce como «plasma» y es la responsable del poder de reflexión de la ionosfera en el caso de las longitudes de onda que abarcan decámetros. Durante el día, los rayos de sol golpean la ionosfera y producen un montón de partículas cargadas. La ionosfera se vuelve inestable y no es capaz de reflejar señales de radio con eficiencia. Pero de noche, la ionosfera está menos perturbada y actúa casi como un espejo liso. ¡Por esta razón, los operadores de radio no profesionales prefieren enviar sus llamaras de larga distancia durante la noche!

trans-unit.id: While light can propagate in empty spaces, sound cannot. This is because sound waves need a medium they can vibrate into. You can listen to a piano melody because each time the pianist presses a key, a small hammer hits a string and makes it vibrate. The vibration then propagates into the air, until it reaches a receiver like a human ear for example. The ear is in fact a small vibrating membrane (the ear-drum) connected to small bones that transmits the vibration to our nervous system.

trans-unit.id: One crucial parameter when observing the sky is the spatial resolution. The spatial resolution is the smallest detail a telescope can observe. The smaller it is, the more details you will observe on your source. The resolution of a telescope, Θ, is proportional to the wavelength, λ, at which you are observing, and inversely proportional to the diameter of the telescope, Φ. Or simply put: So, the more precision we want, the bigger the telescope must be, especially at high wavelengths. How big? Well, let’s do the maths. Let say I want to see someone standing on the Moon with an optical telescope., and to see him with a bit of detail, I want to make an image of him that has a height of 10 pixels. The man on the Moon is 2m tall. First, let’s calculate his apparent size. The apparent size is the angle δ under which an object of size d is seen at a distance D. Using trigonometric relations, it’s fairly easy to find that sin(δ) = d/D. As δ is very small, this simplifies to δ ≈ d/D.

O símplemente: cuanta mayor precisión deseemos, más grande debe ser el telescopio; especialmente en el caso de longitudes de onda elevadas. ¿Cómo de grande? Bien, vamos a hacer un poco de matemáticas. Digamos que quiero mirar a alguien que está de pie en la Luna con un telescopio óptico y para verle con un poco de detalle, quiero capturar una imagen de él que tenga una altura de 10 píxeles. El hombre en la Luna mide 2 metros. Primero que todo, calculemos su tamaño aparente. El tamaño aparente en el ángulo δ bajo el cual un objeto de tamaño «d» se ve a una distancia «D». Si utilizamos relaciones trigonométricas, es bastante fácil averiguar que sin(δ) = d/D. Como δ es muy pequeño, se simplifica en δ ≈ d/D.

trans-unit.id: Here, D is the distance to the Moon, which is hidden somewhere in this poster. If you want to calculate δ be careful that d and D are in the same units! You obtain δ in radian. Now, we said we need 10 pixels to sample our image of the man, so our spatial resolution Θ should be equal to δ/10 Using the formula of the spatial resolution, and the center wavelength of the visible spectrum (it’s probably somewhere on another poster, you will have to look for it – again: be careful with the units!), you can now calculate the diameter of the telescope you will have to build. You have it? Here’s a hint: it’s roughly the width of Central park in New York. It’s also 3 times the height of the Eiffel Tower… This explains why astronomers always thrive for bigger telescopes! And the spatial resolution issue becomes critical at longer wavelengths. For radio observations, the telescopes are gigantic.

trans-unit.id: In a simple two-element radio interferometer, the signals from source alternately arrive in phase and out of phase as the Earth rotates and causes a change in the difference in path (the “d” on the picture) from the radio source to the two elements of the interferometer. This produces interference fringes in a manner similar to what was shown in the double slit experiment with visible light. If the radio source has finite angular size, then “d” varies across the source. The measured interference fringes from the interferometer pair thus depend on the detailed nature of the radio «brightness» distribution in the sky. For a radio interferometer with several antennas, each pair produces different fringes, and information from the fringes can be used to reconstruct the original image.

trans-unit.id: What is the receiver made of? As we are going to tackle the technical aspect of radio observations, we should adapt a bit our vocabulary. It will be more practical to talk about frequencies instead of wavelengths, because hardware sample the incoming signal at a certain frequency rate. If the radio signal is expressed in frequency too, it’s more convenient to compare them to each other. And switching from wavelength λ to frequency υ, is easy: we use this simple relation υ=c/λ (where c is the speed of light) In a simple chain of acquisition, the first element that collects the radio signal is a small antenna, which can take several forms depending on the wavelength. For short radio wavelengths, millimetres for example, the antenna is a corrugated horn, plugged to a waveguide. For longer wavelengths like centimetre, a simple copper wire is enough.

Será más práctico hablar de «frecuencias» en lugar de «longitudes de onda», ya que las herramientas (el hardware) muestran la señal entrante a una frecuencia determinada. Si la señal de radio está expresada también en frecuencia, es más conveniente compararlas entre ellas. Y el cambio de una longitud de onda λ a una frecuencia «υ» es sencillo: utilizamos esta relación simple υ=c/λ (donde «c» es la velocidad de la luz). En una simple cadena de adquisición, el primer elemento que recopila la señal de radio es una antena pequeña, la cual puede tomar diferentes formas dependiendo de la longitud de onda. Para longitudes de onda de radio cortas (milímetros, por ejemplo), la antena es un cuerno corrugado que conecta con una guía de ondas. Para longitudes de onda más largas (como centímetros) es suficiente con un simple alambre de cobre.

trans-unit.id: The small antenna is then linked to a filter that selects the range of frequencies around the frequency of interest. A high frequency amplifier boosts the resulting signal. Once amplified, the trick is to convert the analog signal (a smoothly variating voltage) to a digital signal (an encoded version). But the source frequencies are too high to be sampled with any ordinary hardware! The sample rate is just too high, even an expensive state-of-the-art analog to digital converter could not do it… But here is a simple solution: why not shift the frequency to a much lower one, so that it can be analysed?! Well, this is called heterodyne detection, and it is a technique that is frequently used in radio reception, not only in astronomy, but also in communication.

Un amplificador de alta frecuencia incrementa la señal resultante. Una vez amplificada, el truco reside en convertir la señal analógica (un voltaje que varía muy suavemente) en una señal digital (una versión codificada). ¡Pero las frecuencias de la fuente son demasiado altas para mostrarlas con un hardware corriente! La media de la muestra es simplemente demasiado alta: ni siquiera un conversor moderno y costoso de analógico a digital podría hacerlo...Pero, aquí tenemos una solución sencilla: ¿por qué no cambiar la frecuencia a una mucho más baja para que pueda ser analizada? Bien, esto se llama «detección heterodina» y es una técnica muy común en radio-recepción, no solo para astronomía, sino para comunicación.

trans-unit.id: In heterodyne detection, the signal is mixed with a known signal, generated locally by a stable laser. It is called the Local Oscillator. The Local Oscillator has a frequency (FLO) close to that of the sky signal (FSKY), and it can be tuned so that the difference between FLO and FSKY is equal to a fixed frequency that is called the Intermediate Frequency. To put it simply: F SKY - F LO = F Intermediate The Intermediate Frequency is just the right frequency to be sampled by cheaper hardware, less difficult to build and more reliable. Once converted into bits, the signal can be analysed by software and shifted back to the real observed frequency just by numerically adding back again FLO.

trans-unit.id: The Sun is one of the closest astronomical radio sources. Most of its radio emission comes from its corona, a layer above the photosphere where there are a lot of charged particles forming what is called plasma. Radio emission can also arise from magnetic storms, which form spots on its surface.

trans-unit.target: El Sol es una de las fuentes astronómicas de radio más cercana. La emisión de radio también puede surgir de tormentas magnéticas que forman puntos sobre su superficie.

trans-unit.id: Pulsars the radio lighthouses of the Universe. Like a spinning top, a pulsar is rotating along itself continuously. The radio beams emitted by the pulsar follow its rotation, like a lighthouse on a sea shore. They are received on Earth as short signals (“bip bip bip”). Nearly 2000 pulsars have been observed in our Galaxy and billions exists in the whole Universe.

Los rayos de radio emitidos por el púlsar siguen su rotación, exactamente como un faro en la orilla del mar. En la Tierra las recibimos como señales cortas («bip, bip, bip». En nuestra galaxia se han observado cerca de 2.000 púlsar y hay billones en todo el Universo.

trans-unit.id: What information can we deduce from radio observations? As you should know by now, the spatial resolution of a radio telescope is not that great, unless it’s a huge telescope of 300 m of diameter or an interferometer. For example, a 3m telescope like the one of the EU-HOU project has a resolution of 5°. It’s ten times the angular size of the Sun! So, no image? Not with a 3m telescope, no. But with an interferometer, like the Plateau de Bure Interferometer for example, you can make some beautiful pictures like this one for example: It traces the molecular content of a nearby galaxy called the Whirlpool galaxy. Remember, your eyes cannot see radio emission, so astronomers used this colour scale is here to help us: blue is not very intense, and red is the most intense. That means that when it’s the reddest, there are a lot of molecules in there!

trans-unit.id: As the photon approaches, its wavelength is shortened in front of it. If it’s originally a yellow photon, then it’s colour turns to blue. We call that a blueshift. If the photon is going away, then that’s the other way around, the wavelength becomes longer. For our yellow photon, its colour turns to red. It’s a redshift! So the Doppler effect gives information about the speed of what we are observing. For example, you can see if a star if moving away from us or if it’s coming in our direction, and we can know at what speed it moves. It’s very useful because knowing the kinematic of the object you are observing allow you to try to reproduce it’s behaviour with computer programs, it’s called modelling. Once you have reproduce a computer model that fits a lot of observation, you can apply it to predict other observations, or guess what’s going to happen to your source in a billion years. For example, with a 3m telescope, you can observe the hydrogen emission line at 21cm. Pointing it to the Milky Way will give you a spectrum, which in that case is the density of hydrogen with respect to its velocity. If along your line of sight you intercepted two spiral arms of the Milky Way moving at a different speed, your spectrum will have two peaks, each at the velocity of its respective arm. So, with radio observation, I can reconstruct the spiral arms of the Milky Way. How cool is that?!

trans-unit.id: The EU-HOU (Hands-On Universe, Europe) project uses the excitement of doing real astronomy as a vector to boost science education all over Europe. With the use of state-of-the-art astronomy products combined with new technologies, the project aims at renewing the interest of primary and secondary students for sciences. On the website www.euhou.net, pedagogical resources are available in multiple form. It can be hands-on experiment, exercises, as well as real-time observation with telescopes from all over Europe. With the worldwide Square Kilometre Array and Atacama Large Millimetre Array projects aiming at building the biggest radio observatories ever, radioastronomy is entering a new golden age and will unveil the Universe as never before. In that context, since 2010 the EU-HOU project took a big step towards radio astronomy, by deploying the first European network of radiotelescopes for education, enabling schools to explore the Milky Way through Internet, and IBSE pedagogical resources to be used in the classrooms.
